description: {"blocks":[{"key":"bahtf","text":"Photogrammetry is a method of calculating the three-dimensional shape of an object from a set of images. The advantages of Photogrammetry include the ability to record the shape of an object in a short time and with high accuracy without contact. In addition, the generated model can be displayed without textures. Here, the High Resolution Photogrammetry method is presented, which describes the use of photogrammetric techniques to take pictures and generate models. This method aims to give a comprehensive and extensive description for the development of high resolution 3D models, merging the well known techniques used in academic and computer graphic fields, allowing anyone to independently produce high resolution and quantifiable models for any need.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}
guidelines: {"blocks":[{"key":"5sb6h","text":"In the following protocol, typographical emphases and brackets have been used for software and in-text references.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4cacv","text":"They are: (1) main sub-steps and softwares in bold, e.g. Add imagery and Adobe Photoshop; (2) \"software functions\" in \"quotation marks\", e.g. \"Copy correction settings\"; (3) \u003ckeyboard buttons\u003e in \u003cangle markers\u003e, e.g. \u003cright click\u003e or \u003cDel\u003e.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":57,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":73,"length":15}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

Nevertheless, in recent years the quality of cell phone photos has increased, and there are several Photogrammetry softwares on iPhone systems that can be used to scan easily. However, due to the limited image quality, scanning with mobile phones is not suitable for accurate scanning that requires less than millimeter accuracy.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"safety","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4mcvo","text":"If using a mobile phone, scans will never be as accurate and precise and they could be when using a digital camera. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2obvg","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7a4r2","text":"Although it is possible to take excellent quality scans with a mobile phone, several considerations and extra steps are necessary to achieve this. As mobile phones to not usually have manual control for photography, extra-party softwares are required. Furthermore, photographs should be taken in RAW (DNG) format, using a remote control and adequate lighting.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1bs7c","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5632u","text":"Furthermore. due to the small sensor size of mobile phone cameras, it is often necessary to take more pictures or to get closer to the object to achieve high-detail models. Although this is not problematic when wanting to apply this method to simple objects, complex or more detail objects will be extremely difficult to correctly photograph. In turn, DSLR or mirrorless camera will give better results with less time and effort.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"9qhfn","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6rd2l","text":"Set the camera on a tripod.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f44k0","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"av7ci","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"192a0","text":"Please note that the camera support greatly depends on the surroundings where the photographic station has been set up. Tripods work best on open spaces. On tighter spaces, photography arms with a clamp to attach to stable surfaces (such as tables) are more suitable.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"e8f56","text":"Set the turntable on the table and set the items you want to scan on it, placing it as central as possible.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ddl81","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ee2p7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5o8ui","text":"It is recommended to use the remote control shutter with between 2 to 10 second timer to avoid shake and bluriness. If the camera does not include one, remote control can be accessed via WiFi or Bluetooth; both Android and iOS universal applications exist for this purpose.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cb6ms","text":"If using a turntable, lighting for photogrammetry does not need to be completely uniform (360 degrees), but you need to keep the front lighting as uniform as possible. Diffused lighting is also recommended.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dhg63","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b5ajb","text":"Ring lights are a good choice, but you can also choose 2 or more LED lights set on the left and right sides of the camera.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b6p90","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"bps04","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"35gnh","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3u1gn","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"1reil","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"fipc","text":"Ring flashes (such as the Godox Witstro AR400) will give efficient and bright lighting, however are somewhat expensive. LED lights are not bright enough however they are very cheap.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"26CE71403D7E11ECB1FC11756B911184","height":288.82907010165127,"id":216086,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"bdbg2","text":"Example of front, diffused lighting.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/jpeg","original_name":"1.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gva2bgrsx.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gvaybgrsx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gvazbgrsx.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gvaxbgrsx.webp","width":304.3218171569122}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bdisr","text":"RAW format (CR2, CRW, NEF, PEF...) is usually preferred for photogrammetry, this will provide a wider color gamut and more correct color calibration in post-processing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6rk6d","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"87f8u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7nbem","text":"If high resolution of color and final model is not of importance, JPG/JPEG formats can also be used resulting in a more convenient and faster option.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"djc53","text":"Manual mode is usually selected because we want to have no difference in brightness during photography.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9qr9u","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":[]},{"key":"8bg5u","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8nlli","text":"Manual mode is always suggested to use for photogrammetric purposes.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7pt8h","text":"Changing the brightness does not change the model generation results to a certain extent, however, it directly affects the texture generation. For some items with extreme contrast, brightness can be changed at times during the process, but will require some practice to use this effectively.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"beerh","text":"Aperture.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6fdf8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cdai6","text":"Regular Photogrammetry usually selects an aperture between F/5.6 and F/16. Different aperture sizes depend on the focal length and the size of the subject. Too small aperture will cause diffraction and reduce the quality of the photo, while too big aperture will reduce the depth of field.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bn5k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2bgqr","text":"Generally, for small objects an aperture of F/11 is suggested. Higher apertures such as F/16 are necessary in some cases if the object is too small, however this requires a high-quality lens (e.g. SEL90M28G) so to avoid diffraction.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"989c9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ammat","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ans7a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":14,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"88j15","text":"Depth of field can be calculated according to the set aperture. Depth of field can be calculated from the focal length, distance to subject, the acceptable circle of confusion size and aperture .","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7fg8u","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":26,"offset":42,"style":"bold"}],"key":"6r2v2","text":"The object should always be placed in the middle of the camera frame, which indirectly determines the distance from the camera to the object, as well as the depth of field.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"808sd","text":"Exposure. Setting exposure time and ISO","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"607bg","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"75n4e","text":"First set ISO to an optional value such as 200 (high ISO values will result in noisy images). Call up the histogram in the camera and try to shoot the object. Adjust the exposure time to the appropriate time so that the vertical part of the histogram representing the subject is in the middle and the highlighted part of the histogram.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"cmtg3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"81aa","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a0k7t","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"ai6f3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"69ua9","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3b6uo","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"4dnol","text":"If you are using LED lighting, the exposure time will usually be very long at this time. Reduce the exposure time and or you can increase the ISO value slightly. Until the ISO does not cause too much noise in your photos and the exposure time is at an acceptable value (too long an exposure time can make the photography process too long).","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3qa80","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6lksb","text":"If you use flash light, this adjustment will become easier.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8vj8","text":"However, I usually recommend using at least ISO200 instead of ISO100, because ISO200 does not cause much noise and will provide a shutter speed of one stop.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"1":{"type":"safety","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"47c3q","text":"If the photo is very dark, a lower ISO will not make the overall noise less, as the noise in the dark areas will be amplified when the exposure is increased in post-processing.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"A5975CB09EF111ECA7451FF706AB2459","height":136.0363636363637,"id":216090,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":51,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"d9lih","text":"Sample images with different shutter and ISO values","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":38,"style":"bold"}],"key":"dsgne","text":"Left - Aperture f/2.5, shutter 1/3s,   ISO 100, -0.33 EV exposure compensation","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":7,"offset":40,"style":"bold"}],"key":"867rt","text":"Center - Aperture f/2.5, shutter 1/60s, ISO 100,  4 EV exposure compensation","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":8,"offset":39,"style":"bold"}],"key":"5mhgt","text":"Right - Aperture f/2.5, shutter 1/60s, ISO 1600","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/jpeg","original_name":"Asset 1@2x-100.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gva6bgrsx.jpg","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gva4bgrsx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gva5bgrsx.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gva3bgrsx.webp","width":580}}}}

In the case where perfect color wants to be represented, Cross-Polarization needs to be adjusted, followed by very complex correction in post-processing. These steps are not explicated in this protocol, as perfect color representation falls outside the scope of this method, and it will add further steps to the protocol.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9nrd4","text":"Set white balance.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":18}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"533vj","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"feo7h","text":"You can set an arbitrary white balance when taking pictures and adjust it in post-processing. If possible, use a gray card or color checker and adjust the white balance based on it in post-processing.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9a6qt","text":"METHOD 1 - If the object can be placed on a turntable, place the object on it and take a photograph inbetween slight rotations of the turntable (e.g. 15° or 30°). Repeat the process until the object ends in its original position (360°).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":11}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e5gud","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"70krf","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"afrm4","text":"Ideally, more rotations are photographs of the object the better it will be. The rotations should be envisioned as a full equally distanced \"sphere\" of photographs around the object. Consider 5 as a minumum number of rotations for a high quality final model.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c4s54","text":"Change the placement of the object onto the turntable to so show faces of the object which were not previously in frame (visible through the camera). Repeat step 11 for each placement of the object until you have photograph every face or side.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2hgup","text":"Place the object on the turntable or holder, make sure it is centered on the turntable. The whole object should always be within the frame of the camera. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"389q8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9ccsm","text":"Press the shutter by remote control and rotate the turntable. Ideally, a minimum of 18 times per rotation is preferred.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"45t3g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5pse3","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"7kk34","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8uno8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1ejgg","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8djna","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"edl64","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"","data":{"guid":"317317D03D7F11ECB1FC11756B911184","height":263.92000138716264,"id":216098,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cura2","text":"Example of lithic artefact on holder. Note the marking every 45° on the base, with relevant  0° point at the base of the turntable.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]},"mime":"image/jpeg","original_name":"FBgF4WnWUAE4lMs.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gvbebgrsx.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gvbcbgrsx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gvbdbgrsx.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gvbbbgrsx.webp","width":384.0105840289405}},"1":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":77,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"12rlt","text":"It is essential to include a scale in the photographs of the selected object. Ideally, the scale should be fully visible in at least 4 or 5 of the photos so to aid in the alignment of all the photographs.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"","data":{"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"aq1q3","text":"If the object cannot be rotated, the object can also be placed in the middle of a table, with the photographed rotating and scanning 360° around the object. This requires a strong light source, and it is suggested to use a strobe mounted on the camera. This method is commonly used and it will provide a very quick photo process. However, because it is done manually by a person, there will be quality deviations between photos.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5qu7f","text":"General photography methods and ideas.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":38}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"dc70k","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4v3ec","text":"Because the basic way of photogrammetry's three-dimensional reconstruction is parallax, we need to take at least 2 photos of each surface of the subject. {"blocks":[{"key":"4bll8","text":"The following steps (6-14) present photographic methods and theories which are fundamental for the correct capturing of photographs for photogrammetric purposes. Further detailed explanation for all the discussed techniques and functions can by consulting the \"Small Object and Artefacts Photography\" protocol (dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.b53zq8p6).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":311,"length":41}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"0D11AF979EF011ECA0CF0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://dx.doi.org/10.17504/protocols.io.b53zq8p6"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"7fqtm","text":"METHOD 2 - If the object can't be placed properly onto different faces, change the height and position of the camera so to frame the object at different angles and take photographs in a circular motion. Repeat this action making sure to photograph the object's upper and lower face.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"334le","text":"When changing the height of the camera, it can also be moved closer to the object. This will make the distance between the camera and the object consistent.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ar7ju","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"9tpud","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"D08635D09EF711ECA7451FF706AB2459","height":449,"id":216198,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":7,"offset":53,"style":"italic"}],"key":"6v65j","text":"Visual representation of Method 1 and 2 explained in Step 12. In grey the rotating turntable is shown. In red are the virtual positions of the camera lens, showing the variation in height at constant distance for each of the two methods. Note that Method 1 is used for an object than can be placed comfortably on different faces, while Method 2 is used for an object which can be placed without the aid of external holders only on two separate faces.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}},"mime":"image/jpeg","original_name":"photo methods-01.jpg","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gveibgrsx.jpg","shadow":true,"source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gvegbgrsx.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gvehbgrsx.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gvefbgrsx.webp","width":550}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"cujud","text":"Download the attached .zip file, and try following each step to produce your very own 3D model of this quartzite levallois core!","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":128}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6pm25","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bl1ct","text":"Start from Step 15 if you wish to start by processing the RAW images, or skip to Step 26 if you want to go straight to the photogrammetric processing!","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":11,"length":7},{"style":"italic","offset":81,"length":7}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"qrau","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"5t042","text":"  ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8776j","text":"(The following .zip file contains the original RAW images used for producing the 3D model presented in this protocol)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6fvc1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bs4c2","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"file","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"83126B609FA711ECA7451FF706AB2459","height":0,"id":216072,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"application/x-zip-compressed","original_name":"Teaching Example_Tang, Cerasoni, Hallett, 2022_HRP.zip","placeholder":"https://www.protocols.io/img/extensions/zip.png","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/gvaibgrsx.zip","type":5,"width":0}}}}
